children.definition: manage adroitly, πρὸς ταῦτα Κλέων παλαμάσθω Ar. Ach. 659, cf. Nu. 176, E. Fr. 918 (lyr.); τόλμημα παλαμήσασθαι plan a daring deed, Ar. Pax 94; μηχανάς Philostr. VA 2.33.— Act. only in aor. part. παλαμήσας· τεχνάσας, Hsch.

definition: παλάμη, ἡ, Ep. gen. and dat. παλάμηφι, -φιν:—poet. Noun,

children.definition: palm of the hand: hence, generally, hand, esp. as used in grasping, παλάμῃ δʼ ἔχε χάλκεον ἔγχος Od. 1.104; ἔγχος ὅ οἱ παλάμηφιν ἀρήρει Il. 3.338, cf. 1.238, etc.; παλάμᾳ δονέων Pi. P. 1.44.

hand as used in deeds of violence, ἔπασχον ὑπʼ Ἄρηος παλαμάων by the hands of Ares, Il. 3.128, cf. 5.558, A. Supp. 865 (lyr.); Κυπρογενήας παλάμαισιν Alc. 60: hence, a deed of force, ῥέξαι παλάμαν S. Ph. 1206 (lyr.).
hand as used in works of art, etc., Il. 15.411, Hes. Th. 580, Sc. 219, 320; ἐργατίναις π. IG 12(2).129 (Mytil.).

children.label: II
children.definition: cunning, art, device, either in good or bad sense, π. βιότου a device for oneʼs livelihood, Thgn. 624, cf. Hdt. 8.19; esp. of the gods, θεοῦ σὺν παλάμᾳ, θεῶν παλάμαι, παλάμαις Διός, by their arts, Pi. O. 10(11).21, P. 1.48, N. 10.65; ὦ παλάμαι θεῶν S. Ph. 177 (lyr.); πυκνότατος παλάμαις, of Sisyphus, Pi. O. 13.52, cf. A. Pr. 167 (lyr.), etc.; παντοίας πλέκειν παλάμας Ar. V. 645.

children.label: III
children.definition: piece of handiwork, work of art, Hsch. (pl.); πυριγενὴς π., i.e. a sword, E. Or. 820 (lyr.). (Cf. Lat. palma, OE. folm ‘hand’.)

definition: Παλαμήδης, ὁ, voc. ες Ar. Ra. 1451; gen. ους E. Or. 433, etc.; dat. ει Pl. Ap. 41b, εϊ Q.S. 5.198; acc. η Pl. Ep. 311b, εα E. IA 198 (lyr.); but some forms occur of 1 decl., dat. ῃ Hsch. s.v. ἄκεστρον; acc. ην Pl. Phdr. 261d: ( παλάμη):—

children.definition: Palamedes, i.e. the Inventor, Ar. Th. 770, Ra. 1451, Paus. 2.20.3:—hence Adj. Πᾰλᾰμήδειος, α, ον, worthy of Palamedes, ingenious, βούλευμα Alciphr. 3.4; ἀβάκιον EM 666.21; also Πᾰλᾰμηδικός, ή, όν, Π. τοὐξεύρημα Eup. 351.6.
device, scheme, Com.Adesp. 706, Ael. NA 1.32.
Alex.Trall. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: Cyran. 22.

children.label: III
children.definition: παλαμίς· τεχνίτης παρὰ τοῖς Σαλαμινίοις, Hsch.
one guilty of violence: hence, murderer, τινος S. Tr. 1207; one defiled by blood-guiltiness, A. Eu. 448, S. El. 587, Hyp. Fr. 85; ὦ παλαμναίη O miscreant!, of the fox, Babr. 82.6.
Adj., τῷ π. ξένῳ the abominable stranger, Phryn.Com. 58; ἱκεσίαι a murdererʼs supplications, A.R. 4.709; ἀσπίς Orph. L. 512; π. μόρον ἕξει a miscreantʼs death, prob. in Supp.Epigr. 1.442 ( Lydia).

children.label: II
children.definition: avenger of blood, μὴ παλαμναῖον λάβω E. IT 1218, cf. X. Cyr. 8.7.18 (pl.); in full, δαίμονες π. avenging deities, Ti.Locr. 105, cf. Plu. Oth. 1, Jul. Caes. 336b; Ζεὺς π. Arist. Mu. 401a23, cf. Plb. Fr. 98, Poll. 5.131, EM 647.43.
laying on of a preliminary coat of paint, priming, IG 42(1).109 iii 111, 117 ( Epid., iii B. C.).
Ar. Pax 574 codd. (lyr.; παλάθιον Suid.).

definition: παλάσσω, pf. Pass. πεπάλαγμαι, Ep. Verb,

children.definition: besprinkle, defile, αἵματί τʼ ἐγκεφάλῳ τε παλαξέμεν . . οὖδας Od. 13.395:—mostly in Pass., παλάσσετο δʼ αἵματι θώρηξ Il. 5.100; αἵματι καὶ λύθρῳ πεπαλαγμένον Od. 22.402, cf. Call. Lav.Pall. 7; πεπάλακτο πόδας καὶ χεῖρας ὕπερθεν Od. 22.406; αἰδοῖα γονῇ πεπαλαγμένος Hes. Op. 733; νιφετῷ π. ὕδωρ Q.S. 12.410:—in Med., παλάσσετο χεῖρας he bespattered his hands, Il. 11.169.

data.quote: αἵματί τʼ ἐγκεφάλῳ τε παλαξέμεν . . οὖδας

children.definition: Pass., to be scattered abroad, ἐγκέφαλος πεπάλακτο ib. 98, 12.186.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ἀσωπὸς . . πεπάλακτο κεραυνῷ was smitten, for ἐπέπληκτο, Call. Del. 78.

children.label: III
children.definition: pf. Med., shake, i.e. draw lots from an urn, κλήρῳ νῦν πεπάλαχθε διαμπερές determine your fate by lot, Il. 7.171; τοὺς ἄλλους κλήρῳ πεπαλάχθαι ἄνωγον Od. 9.331; πεπάλαχθε κατὰ κληῗδας ἐρετμά A.R. 1.358.— Aristarch. read πεπάλασθε, πεπαλάσθαι in Hom. (cf. πάλλω).

palm of the hand: hence, as a measure of length, palm, four fingers’ breadth, IG 1(2).372.35, Cratin. 133, IG 2(2).1665.10, 1666 A 67,70, al. (iv B. C.), 11 (2).287 A 95 ( Delos, iii B. C.), CIG 2860.14 ( Delos), cf. Phryn. 264, PLit.Lond. 183:—also παλαιστή, Hp. Nat.Mul. 33, Arist. HA 606a14, PCair.Zen. 484.11 (iii B. C.), Plb. 1.22.4, Hero Aut. 3.1, *Geom. 4.1, D.S. 1.55, etc.; also παλαιστής, οῦ, ὁ, LXX Ex. 25.23(25), 3 Ki. 7.24, Hero *Deff. 131, *Geom.4.10, S.E. M. 9.300; written παλεστής, POxy. 669.27, 34 (iii A. D.); cf. παλαιστιαῖος.
a palm long, broad, or high, ὕψος π. Hdt. 1.50, cf. IG 2(2).1675.13, 1693,2492.44; later παλαιστιαῖος (q. v.).
= Lat. Palatium, the Palatine Hill, D.H. 1.31, etc.:—hence Πᾰλᾱτῖνος, η, ον, Palatine, Id. 2.70.
anything acquired by lot, = ἀρχή, λῆξις, μοῖρα, γενεά, Hsch.; ἐκ παλαχῆς, = ἐξ ἀρχῆς, Nic. Th. 449 (cf. Sch.ad loc.); but παλαχῆθεν· ἐκ γενεᾶς, ἐκ παλαιοῦ, Hsch.

definition: παλεομίσημα [ ῑ], ατος, τό, ( παλεός = παλαιός)

children.definition: ancient object of hate, Tim. Pers. 90.
where nymphs were born of old, ἄντρον Tim. Pers. 120 ( -φαιο- Pap.).
allurement, Anon. ap. Bast.ad Greg.Cor. p.1017S.

definition: παλευτά τὰ λίνα οἷς τὰ θηρία ἁλίσκεται, Phot.

children.definition: decoy-bird, Hsch.
παλευτής, Arist. HA 613a23: as Adj., πελειάδες Ael. NA 13.17: metaph., of courtesans, φιλῳδοὶ κερμάτων π. Eub. 84.1:—also παλ-ευτρίς, ίδος, ἡ, Phot.
act as decoy-birds, Ar. Av. 1083, 1087:— Pass., of a bird, to be decoyed, Philostr. Im. 2.33.

children.label: II
children.definition: π. τινά decoy, entrap, Plu. Adul. 2.52b, Sull. 28, etc.; π. τινὰ τοῖς ἀφροδισίοις Philostr. VA 4.25: abs., Ph. 1.654.

to be disabled, εἰ παλήσειε ὁ ναυτικὸς στρατός Hdt. 8.21: elsewh. only in Hsch., παλήσειε· διαφθαρείη. ἐπάλησεν· ἐφθάρη. πεπαληκέναι· ἐκπεσεῖν. πεπαλημέναι· βεβλαμμέναι: also in shortd. forms, πεπαλμένος· βεβλαμμένος, Id., Phot.; πεπαλκέναι λέγεται τὸ ἐκπίπτειν τὰ πλοῖα Id.

wrestling, Il. 23.635; ἢ πὺξ ἠὲ πάλῃ ἢ καὶ ποσίν Od. 8.206: κρατέων πάλα Pi. O. 8.20; νικᾶν πυγμὴν καὶ π. E. Alc. 1031. cf. Hp. Acut.(Sp.) 62, Th. 1.6, Pl. Lg. 795b, Plu. QConv. 2.638d, Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.28.3; τίνα π. ἐμάνθανες ; Ar. Eq. 1238; παίδων, ἐφήβων νεωτέρων, μέσων, πρεσβυτέρων, ἀνδρῶν π., SIG 959 ( Chios), cf. IG 5(2).549.16,30 ( Lycosura, iv B. C.), etc.

data.quote: ἢ πὺξ ἠὲ πάλῃ ἢ καὶ ποσίν

children.definition: fight, battle, ἅπτειν πάλην τινί A. Ch. 866 (anap.); π. δορός E. Heracl. 159.

definition: πάλη [ᾰ] (B) (or παλή acc. to Sch. Il. 10.7, to dist. it from foreg.), ἡ,

children.definition: the finest meal, π. ἀλφίτου Hp. Mul. 1.64, cf. Ruf. Ren.Ves. 6.7, Arching. ap. Gal. 12.791; π. πυρίνη Lycus ap. Orib. 9.51.1; νάρθηκος πάλαι Zopyr. ap. eund. 14.61.1.
any fine dust, ἀνέπλησα τὠφθαλμὼ πάλης φυσῶν τὸ πῦρ Pherecr. 60, cf. Hsch. (Cf. Lat. pollen, pulvis.)

data.quote: ἀνέπλησα τὠφθαλμὼ πάλης φυσῶν τὸ πῦρ

children.definition: = foreg., π. ὀρόβοιο Nic. Al. 551.

definition: παλημάτιον, τό, Dim. of foreg., Ar. Fr. 682.

πάλι [ᾰ], later poet. form of πάλιν, Call. Epigr. 12, AP 5.181 ( Mel.), Epigr.Gr. 314 ( Smyrna), Orph. H. 3.10, Scymn. 470: also in later Prose, Phld. Mus. pp. 17,40 K., Anon.Lond. 6.36, 18.4, POxy. 298.27 (i A. D.), cf. Phryn. 249.

children.definition: mutual mockery, prob. l. in Ph. 1.528.

rebirth, regeneration, of the world, παλιγγενεσίας ἡγεμόνες, of Noah and his sons, Ph. 2.144; ἡ ἀνάκτησις καὶ π. τῆς πατρίδος J. AJ 11.3.9; renewal of a race, Corp.Herm. 3.3; of persons, beginning of a new life, εἰς π. ὁρμᾶν Ph. 1.159, cf. Luc. Musc.Enc. 7: hence of restoration after exile, Cic. Att. 6.6.4; transmigration, reincarnation of souls, Plu. Es. carn. 2 2.998c; cf. μετεμψύχωσις fin.

data.quote: ἡ ἀνάκτησις καὶ π. τῆς πατρίδος

children.definition: rebirth of the κόσμος, Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.191: pl., ib. 187, Boeth.Stoic. 3.265; so later, ἡ περιοδικὴ π. τῶν ὅλων M.Ant. 11.1, cf. Procl. in Ti. 3.241 D.
relapse, Gal. 13.83; regrowth of a tumour, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.2.7.

children.label: II
children.definition: = restitutio natalium, Just. Nov. 18.11.

children.label: III
children.definition: NT.,
resurrection, Ev.Matt. 19.28.
regeneration by baptism, διὰ λουτροῦ παλιγγενεσίας Ep.Tit. 3.5.
born again, Nonn. D. 2.650; generated anew, αἰών PMag.Lond. 121.510.
contradictory, false, ἀγγέλων ῥῆσις Pi. N. 1.58; but ἔρις οὐ π. un relenting, Id. Parth. 2.63.

children.label: II
children.definition: of strange or foreign tongue, πόλις Id. I. 6(5).24.

children.label: III
children.definition: Com.Adesp. 1098.
bent or doubled back, κέλευθοι Tryph. 523; written παλίγναμπτος in Opp. C. 2.305, H. 1.54.
Hsch.
revision of a γραφή III, Jul. Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).191.
to be a retail dealer, D. 56.7.
retailer of imported produce, Ar. Pl. 1156 ( ὁ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἐμπόρου ἀγοράζων καὶ πωλῶν Sch.): metaph., π. πονηρίας D. 25.46.
bent back, gloss on παλιμπετές, Sch. A.R. 4.1315.
grow malignant, fester, Hp. Fract. 11, 25.
festering, of a wound, Hp. Fract. 31 (pl.).

spiteful, malignant, resentful, ἀλλά τις οὐκ ἔμμι παλιγκότων ὄργαν Sapph. 72; κληδόνες π. injurious, untoward reports, A. Ag. 863, 874; π. τύχη the spitefulness of fortune, ib. 571; πῆμα Pi. O. 2.20; π. ὄψιν ἰδοῦσα a dreadful sight, Mosch. 4.92; τὰ π. λέγειν Antipho Soph. 49.

data.quote: ἀλλά τις οὐκ ἔμμι παλιγκότων ὄργαν

children.definition: hostile, malignant, τινι Ar. Pax 390, Euph. 51.12, etc.; πρὸς πάντα π. Theoc. 22.58; οἱ παλίγκοτοι adversaries, Pi. N. 4.96, A. Supp. 376. Adv., αὐτῷ . . -τως συνεφέρετο it fared ill with him, Hdt. 4.156; φέρειν τὰ συμπίπτοντα μὴ π. to bear accidents not resentfully, E. Fr. 572.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: growing malignant, festering, Hp. Art. 27 ( Sup.).

children.label: III
children.definition: steep, rugged, πάγος τρηχύς τε καὶ π. Archil. 87. (Cf. ἀλλόκοτος).
revision of a κρίσις II.1, Jul.Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).191 (prob.).
recovery of possession, Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr.7.196 (pl.).
redivivus, Gloss.
fishing-net, Plb. Fr. 65.
looking back, cj. in Alcm. 145.
παλιγκαμπής), Sch.Par. A.R. 4.1315.

definition: Παλικοί, οἱ, a lake near Leontini in Sicily, emitting two jets of volcanic gas, Arist. Mir. 834b8, Str. 6.2.9, D.S. 11.88.

children.label: II
children.definition: A. Fr. 6, D.S. l.c.
Hsch.
repeat, recapitulate, ὥς οἱ ἐπαλιλλόγητο [τὸ πρῆγμα] Hdt. 1.118, cf. 90, Arist. Rh.Al. 1433b31, Phld. Po. 5.26, Ph. 2.358, J. AJ 17.5.5, App. Mith. 14, Simp. in Ph. 1159.4.
recapitulation, Arist. Rh.Al. 1433b29: pl., ib. 1428a8.
equivocation, Thphr. Char. 1.7 (pl.).
collected again, Il. 1.126.
loosed again, unloosed, Nonn. D. 35.250, al.
a reversed Βακχεῖος, Heph. 3.2, Aristid.Quint. 1.22, Eust. 1551.54:—hence Adj. πᾰλιμ-βακχειᾰκός, ή, όν, Heph. 13.1.
Call. Fr.anon. 52.
walking back, ἱστῶν παλίμβαμοι ὁδοί, of women working at the loom, since they had to walk to and fro from side to side, Pi. P. 9.18.
living again, Keil-Premerstein Erster Bericht p.9, Hsch., Phot., Suid.
sprouting or growing again, κύων, of the hydra, E. HF 1274; καυλοί Thphr. HP 7.2.4.
ricochetting, βέλος Ruf. Interrog. 60.
change of mind, fickleness, AP 5.301.12 ( Agath.), Agath. 2.6.

reversed, γνώμη Sch. Ar. Nu. 298: hence, untrustworthy, unstable, ἤθη π. καὶ ἄπιστα Pl. Lg. 705a, cf. D.Chr. 31.37, Aristaenet. 1.28; δολερὸς καὶ π. Plu. Crass. 21; τὸ π., = παλιμβολία, Aeschin. 2.40; of a slave, = παλίμπρατος, Men. 445; πέδιλα π. turned or patched sandals, Nic. Fr. 85. Adv. -λως Poll. 3.132.
a wind counter to the prevalent north wind, Thphr. Vent. 28 (pl.).

definition: παλίμβουλος, f.l. for -βολος, Adam. 1.15, Sch. Th. 3.37, Eust. 375.1.

children.definition: renew the fight, Lyd. Mag. 3.55.
repeated change, εἰς σώματα Plu. Es. carn. 2 2.998d.
as long again, doubly long, χρόνος A. Ag. 196 (lyr.).
again a child, Luc. Sat. 9.

definition: παλίμπαστος, ον, dub. l., epith. of πέλαγος, Dion.Byz. 53.

children.definition: recurrence, Theol.Ar. 58.

falling back, Nonn. D. 3.30; recurrent, Theol.Ar. 57: in early writers only in neut. as Adv., back again, ἂψ ἐπὶ νῆας ἔεργε παλιμπετές Il. 16.395; ὡς . . ἐν νηῒ παλιμπετὲς ἀπονέωνται Od. 5.27, cf. Call. Del. 294, A.R. 2.1250, etc.
cobbled shoes, Com.Adesp. 1099.
patching up or cobbling of shoes, Thphr. Char. 22.11.
pitch reboiled, dry pitch, Dsc. 1.72; cf. παλίνπιττα.
back-driven, δρόμοι A. Pr. 838.

definition: παλιμπλάζομαι, Pass., only in aor. part. παλιμπλαγχθείς,

children.definition: foiled, driven back, Il. 1.59, Od. 13.5 (better divisim).
wandering to and fro, Μαίανδρος AP 6.287 (Antip., v.l. πολυπλανής) ; βίοτος Epigr.Gr. 491.5 (Orchom. Boeot.).
twined or plaited back, κύρτοι Opp. H. 4.47.
sailing back, Ael. NA 3.14.
washed up again, vamped up: metaph., of a plagiarist who retouches the works of others and passes them off for his own, κηφὴν π. AP 7.708 ( Diosc.).

definition: παλίμπλωτος, ον, Ion. for παλίμπλους, Lyc. 1431.

children.definition: counter-wind, Thphr. Vent. 26; poet. πᾰλιμ-πνοίη A.R. 1.586 (pl.).
breathing again, Nonn. D. 37.295; poet. πᾰλίμ-πνοιος, η, ον, eddying, δῖναι cj. in Opp. H. 1.771.
retributive, δίκαι Max. 17.

children.label: II
children.definition: παλίμποινα, τά, retribution, repayment, A. Ch. 793 (lyr.).

definition: παλιμπόρευτος, ον, = sq., Tim. Pers. 186, Lyc. 180, 628.

children.definition: going back, φυγή Tim. Pers. 174, cf. Opp. H. 4.529, Nonn. D. 2.247.
reversible cup, Michel 39.37,40 ( Milet., iii B. C.):—also πᾰλιμ-πότης, ου, ὁ, Inscr.Délos 442 B 205 ( ii B. C., pl.).
going back, returning, Lyc. 126, AP 5.162 ( Mel.); π. ἡ τύχη περιίσταται J. BJ 4.1.6.
to be a retailer, PRev.Laws 47.16 (iii B. C.).
Socr. Ep. 1.1.
sold again or by retail, of a good-for-nothing slave who passes from hand to hand, Poll. 3.125.
good-for-nothing, Ph. 2.523, Poll. 4.36; also of things, D.Chr. 31.37, Poll. 7.12.
double treachery, Plb. 5.96.4, D.H. 8.32, D.S. 15.91, etc.
traitor to both sides, Din. Fr. 89.26, D.S. 15.91, App. BC 5.96.
stern-foremost, E. IT 1395, from Hsch., who expl. it οἷον παλίμπρυμνον χώρησιν.
rump-foremost, Arist. PA 659a20, Hsch.
v.l. in Poll. 7.12; esp. of works not completed by the first contractor and given to another, IG 7.3073.26 (Lebad.), BCH 20.324 (ibid.).
back-speaking, recanting, π. ἀοιδά, = παλινῳδία, a song of recantation, reproaching the male sex instead of the female, E. Ion 1096 (lyr.), cf. Med. 415 sq.

children.label: II
children.definition: Tryph. 423, cf. Hsch.; π. εὐχαί Ph. 2.301; ὄναρ ib. 55.
returning, Max. 332, 570, PMich. in Class.Phil. 22.16.
changing oneʼs mind, Lyc. 1349.
growing again, of the hydra, Luc. Am. 2.
deleticia (sc. charta), Gloss.
scraped again, βιβλίον π. palimpsest, Plu. Max. cum princip. 2.779c: -ψηστον, τό, as Subst., Garr. ib. 504d, cf. Cat.22.5, Cic. Fam. 7.18.2.

back, backwards (the usual sense in early Ep.), mostly joined with Verbs of going, coming, etc.; π. χώρει Hdt. 5.72; π. ἐλεύσεται, κατελθεῖν, ἐπανέλθωμεν, A. Pr. 854, S. OC 601, Pl. Cra. 438a, etc.; κέλευθον ἥνπερ ἦλθες ἐγκόνει π. A. Pr. 962; δίκα καὶ πάντα π. στρέφεται E. Med. 412 (lyr.); δεῦρο σωθήσῃ π. Id. Ph. 725, cf. 1400; δόμεναι π. give back, restore, Il. 1.116, etc.; π. ἀποδοῦναι And. 2.23; π. ἀγκαλέσαι to call back, A. Ag. 1021 (lyr.): less freq. c. gen., π. τράπεθʼ υἷος ἑοῖο she turned back from her son, Il. 18.138; δόρυ Ἀχιλλῆος π. ἔτραπεν 20.439, cf. Od. 7.143: coupled with other Advbs., π. αὖτις ἔβαινον νηὸς ἐπὶ γλαφυρῆς 14.356, cf. Pi. O. 1.65; αὖ π. Od. 13.125; ἂψ π. Il. 18.280; π. εἶσιν ὀπίσσω Od. 11.149; π. φέρεσθαι ἐξοπίσω Hes. Th. 181; ἄψορρον π. S. El. 53; π. οἴκαδε, π. οἴκαδʼ αὖ, Ar. Lys. 792, Ra. 1486; π. αὖ Pl. Prt. 318e, etc.: with the Art., ἡ π. ὁδός E. Or. 125.

data.quote: π. αὖτις ἔβαινον νηὸς ἐπὶ γλαφυρῆς

children.definition: contradiction, π. ἐρέει gainsay, Il. 9.56; π. ὅ γε λάζετο μῦθον took back his word, unsaid it, 4.357; opp. ἀληθέα εἰπεῖν, Od. 13.254; μηδέ τῳ δόξῃ π. let no one think contrariwise, A. Th. 1045: in Prose, contrariwise, Pl. Grg. 482d; π. αὖ Id. R. 507b; αὖ . . π. Id. Ap. 27d: in this sense sts. c. gen., τὸ π. νεότατος youthʼs opposite, Pi. O. 10(11).87; χρόνου τὸ π. the change of time, E. HF 777 (lyr.); cf. ἔμπαλιν.

children.label: II
children.definition: again, once more, rare in Hom., Il. 2.276, cf. S. OT 1166, X. Mem. 1.6.11, etc.: freq. coupled with αὖ, αὖθις (q.v.); π. ἐξ ἀρχῆς Ar. Pax 997, etc.; π. καὶ π. Str. 17.1.3, Plu. Vind. 2.565d, Ael. VH 1.4; ἔγχει καὶ π. εἰπέ, π. π. Ἡλιοδώρας" AP 5.135 ( Mel.): both senses (I and II) are appropriate in Od. 16.456, Pl. Prt. 322b, etc.

children.label: III
children.definition: in turn, S. El. 371, Ar. Ach. 342, Call. Dian. 87, etc.; π. ὁ Κῦρος ἠρώτα X. An. 1.6.7; π. ἀπαιτῶ Pl. R. 612d; again, πρῶτον μέν . . ἔπειτα π. Arist. Pol. 1289b29, etc. (In compos. πάλιν sts. means doubly, as in παλιμμήκης, παλίνσκιος.)
bringing messages to and fro, Hsch., Phot., Suid.

to be taken back or recalled, οὐ π. οὐδʼ ἀπατηλόν ir revocable, Il. 1.526; π. ἀάτη Hes. Sc. 93; νεότατα δʼ ἔχειν π. οὐκ ἔστι Theoc. 29.28; π. αἰών, ἀρχή, etc., Nonn. D. 3.255, 6.175, al.; recoverable, of an element, Numen. ap. Eus. PE 15.17.

data.quote: νεότατα δʼ ἔχειν π. οὐκ ἔστι

children.definition: retracting his words, of the philosopher Arcesilaus, Id.ib. 14.5.
removed from office and re-elected, of public officers, Eup. 89, Archipp. 14, Nicostr. 34.
pulled down and rebuilt, patched up, Pi. Fr. 84, cf. Harp. s.v., Hsch., etc.; also σιδήρου π. IG 1(2).313.131 ( Eleusis).
παλιναίρετα γεγονότα . . καὶ διεφθαρμένα Pl. Ti. 82e, expld. by Tim. Lex. φευκτά, ἔκβλητα, τὸ ἐναντίον . . αὐτῇ τῇ αἱρέσει πάθος ἐμποιοῦντα.
growing again, APl. 16.221 ( Theaet.), Nonn. D. 25.542.
deserting back again, double deserter, X. HG 7.3.10.
learnt again, Hsch.
go to law again, bring a fresh action, BGU 613.17 (ii A. D.), Hsch.
second action, new trial, π. διδόναι τινί Hdn. 7.6.4; π. εὑρίσκειν Plu. Dem. 6; μὴ ἦμεν . . π. Tab.Heracl. 1.157.
litigious, Crates Com. 51.
whirling round and round, θάλασσα AP 9.73 ( Antiphil.); κόσμοιο παλινδίνητον ἀνάγκην ib. 1.19 ( Claudian.), cf. 9.505.14.
eddying of water, Hsch.
App. Pun. 46, D.C. 74.6.
mending of shoes: hence in concrete, mended shoes, Pl.Com. 164, cf. Poll. 6.164.

run back again, ἐπὶ τόπον J. BJ 3.2.3; ἐς ταὐτά Aret. SD 1.6: abs., Manetho ap. J. Ap. 1.26; of a ship, Ps.- Hdt. Vit.Hom. 19, D.S. 20.74, Plu. Cic. 32: prov., παλινδρομῆσαι μᾶλλον ἢ κακῶς δραμεῖν Luc. Asin. 18.

children.label: II
children.definition: go back without coming to a head, of an abscess, dub. in Hp. Prog. 18; μὴ -δρομῇ τὸ ἐρυσίπελας ἔσω strike inwards, ib. 23.

children.label: b
children.definition: recur, relapse, Id. Epid. 2.3.18, Aret. SA 1.7, Luc. Abd. 32.

children.label: c
children.definition: παλινδρομῶν σφυγμός recurrent, recovering, Gal. 9.510, Marcellin. Puls. 400.

children.label: d
children.definition: recurrent nerves, Gal. 8.53, UP 16.4.

children.label: III
children.definition: π. πρὸς τὰς τῶν Καρχηδονίων ἐλπίδας fall back upon . . , Plb. 7.3.8; γεωμετρία ἐπὶ τὰ αἰσθητὰ -δρομοῦσα Plu. QConv. 2.718f.
βλασφημία -δρομοῦσα, of abuse which comes home to roost, ib. Util. 88d.
Aret. SA 2.9.

running back, going backwards, AP 6.307 ( Phan.), Iamb. in Nic. p.76P.; τοῦ ἡλίου D.L. 7.152; τῆς φύσιος ἡ π. restoration, Aret. CD 1.3; striking inwards, of an abscess or eruption, Hp. Prorrh. 2.7: in pl., relapses, Id. Epid. 4.42.
recurring, of the tide, κίνησις Str. 1.3.8.

running back again, π. ἄπιθι Luc. Tim. 37; recurring, σελήνη π. ἀνάμνησις Secund. Sent. 6; π. ἔλλαβε πένθος recurring, Epigr.Gr. 233.7 ( Chios); μνᾶς . . παλινδρόμους ἀπολαβεῖν back again, D.L. 2.65: metaph., uncertain, S.E. P. 2.203.
coming home to roost, πτηνῶν γένη π. PMag.Par. 1.2556.
one who squanders again, Cerc. 4.12.
retail-dealer, Phot.
coming back to life, Opp. H. 1.319 [corr. from Supp.]
returning calm, AP 10.102 ( Bass.; v.l. πολυν-).
sinking, settling down, Hp. Hum. 2.
return of rejected blocks to a quarry, Supp.Epigr. 4.453.30 ( Didyma, ii B. C.).
returning, Nonn. D. 6.62, al.
retrace oneʼs path: hence in Math., recur, of numbers, Theol.Ar. 22.
retracing oneʼs path: hence, recurrence of numbers, Theol.Ar. 57 (pl.); κατὰ παλινοδίαν ib. 59.

definition: παλίνοπτα τὰ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἡλίου ἀπεστραμμένα, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.127.

children.definition: rushing back, Il. 11.326 (better divisim).
Ar. Ach. 1178, Sch. S. OT 193.

backwards, back, ὡς ὅτε τίς τε δράκοντα ἰδὼν παλίνορσος ἀπέστη Il. 3.33, cf. Emp. 35.1; ἄγε νῆα . . π. ἐς Ἑλλάδα A.R. 1.416; π. φορή retrograde movement, Aret. SA 2.5; recurrent, ἣν ἡ νοῦσος π. ὀφθῇ Id. CD 1.5: neut. as Adv., back again, AP 7.608 ( Eutolm.): Att. πᾰλίνορρον, with a backward wrench, Ar. Ach. 1179. ( -ορσος prob. = ὄρρος, cf. παλιμπυγηδόν.)

data.quote: ὡς ὅτε τίς τε δράκοντα ἰδὼν παλίνορσος ἀπέστη

children.definition: recurring, inveterate, μῆνις A. Ag. 154 (lyr.).
return, Gal. 16.89, Olymp. in Mete. 112.20.
returning, ὁρμή Opp. H. 1.616, cf. Nonn. D. 11.413.
making water again, with play on pr. n. Palinurus, Mart. 3.78.2.

definition: παλίνπιττα ἑφθὴ πίττα, Hsch.; cf. παλίμπισσα.

children.definition: shaded over again, thick-shaded, ἐν -σκίῳ Archil. 34, Plu. Num. 10, cf. Is. Fr. 112; π. ἐλαῖαι Arist. HA 556a24; ὗλαι Luc. Am. 12; dark, χειμών S. Fr. 289:—also πᾰλίσκῐος, ον, ἄντρον h.Merc. 6, h.Hom. 18.6; ἐν -σκίοις Thphr. HP 1.8.1, cf. Od. 40; εἰς τὸ π. Max.Tyr. 5.1.
looking back again, -σκοπιὰν ἔχομεν E. Or. 1262 (lyr.).
safe again, Nonn. D. 25.535 codd. (leg. παλίμπνοον).
return from secession, of the Roman plebs, f.l. for πάλιν ἀστατοῦντος, Lyd. Mag. 1.38.
speak words of ill omen, A. Th. 258.
reversed, βήματα S. Ichn. 112.
turned backward, Κριός Max. 80, cf. Nic. Th. 679 (v.l. παλίστρεπτος).
whirled or twirled round, Lyc. 739.
Opp. C. 2.99; παλίστρ-, Sch. Ar. Nu. 298.
gathered again, Hsch., Phot. s.v. παλίλλογα.
done in requital, παλίντιτα ἔργα γενέσθαι Od. 1.379.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., requiting, πνεύματα Emp. 111.5.
demand for repayment of interest, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.295d.

bent backward, i.e. the opposite way to that in which they were drawn, τόξα, in Hom. of the bow whether strung, Il. 8.266, cf. 15.443; or unstrung, 10.459, Od. 21.11, cf. S. Tr. 511 (lyr.); Ἀράβιοι τόξα π. εἶχον μακρά Hdt. 7.69; Σκυθικὰ π. βέλη A. Ch. 161 (lyr.).
back-stretched, ἡνίαι Ar. Av. 1739.
caused by opposite tensions, π. ἁρμονίη κόσμου ὅκωσπερ λύρης καὶ τόξου Heraclit. 51 (v.l. παλίντροπος).

data.quote: π. ἁρμονίη κόσμου ὅκωσπερ λύρης καὶ τόξου

children.label: II
children.definition: παλίντονα, τά, military engines for throwing stones, but not pointed missiles, = λιθοβόλα, Ph. Bel. 91.36, Hero Bel. 74, 104, etc.
rubbed again and again, of the ass, obstinate, resisting all blows, Semon. 7.43.
knavish, crafty, τὰ . . πανοῦργα καὶ π. S. Ph. 448.

definition: παλίντριψ, ῐβος, ὁ, ἡ, = foreg., Gloss.

children.definition: return, ἐπὶ νῆα -τροπάασθαι A.R. 4.165; ἂψ δὲ -τροπόωντο ib. 643.
Nic. Th. 402.
turning about: in pl., changes of mind, A.R. 3.1157.
turned away, averted, ὄμματα, ὄψις, A. Ag. 777 (lyr.), Supp. 173 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: turning back, π. ἕρπειν, στρέφεσθαι, S. Ph. 1222, E. HF 1069 (lyr.); π. ἐκ πολέμοιο AP 9.61; π. κέλευθος Parm. 6.9.

changing to the other side, contrary, πλάστιγξ τοῦ βίου S. Fr. 576.5 (s. v.l.); π. τῆς ἐλπίδος ἀποβαινούσης πρὸς τὰς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἐπιβολάς Plb. 14.6.6; π. ταῖς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἐλπίσιν exactly contrary to their original expectations, Id. 5.16.9, cf. 9.21.1; π. ποιῆσαι τὴν μάχην D.S. 15.85, cf. App. Mith. 88; π. ποιήσασθαι τὴν δίωξιν Onos. 27 (v.l. παλίστροφον) ; τὸ π. τοῦ δαιμονίου changeableness, Id. 35.4.

data.quote: π. τῆς ἐλπίδος ἀποβαινούσης πρὸς τὰς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἐπιβολάς

children.label: III
children.definition: Act., turning to flight, νόημα B. 10.54.
beaten back, neut. as Adv., A.R. 3.1254.
with a reverse of fortune, τριβὰ βίου A. Ag. 464 (lyr.).
recant an ode: hence, generally, revoke, recant, Pl. Alc. 2.142d, 148b; π. πρὸς τὸ χεῖρον Luc. Apol. 1.
repeat an ode: hence, generally, repeat, Ph. 1.586, S.E. M. 7.202.
one must recant, Gal. 11.224.
palinode, recantation, first used of an ode by Stesichorus, in which he recanted his attack upon Helen, Isoc. 10.64, Pl. Ep. 319e, Phdr. 243b.
recantation, ib. 257a, Cic. Att. 4.5.1, Ph. 1.260, Plu. Alex. 53.
palinodic, i.e. having the form a b b a, of metrical schemes, Heph. Poëm. 4; π. ὕμνοι Cratin. 6 D.
changing and returning with the seasons, Arat. 452.

children.label: II
children.definition: παλινώρους· ἄκοντας, Hsch. ( παλίνωρον is f.l. for παλίνορρον, Id.).
made of παλίουρος, Str. 16.4.17.
ruta, Gloss.

definition: παλίουρος, ὁ ( Thphr. HP 1.3.2, Agatharch. 34) or ἡ ( AP 9.414 ( Tull.Gem.)),

children.definition: Christʼs thorn, Paliurus australis, E. Cyc. 394, Theopomp. Hist. 129, Theoc. 24.89, Dsc. 1.92, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: great jujube, Zizyphus Spina-Christi, Thphr. HP 4.3.3, Agatharch. l.c., BGU 1120.16 (i B. C.), Plin. HN 13.111.

children.label: III
children.definition: Hsch.
made of the wood of the παλίουρος I, AP 6.95 ( Antiphil.).
ebb and flow, Str. 1.3.8, 3.3.3; ἀέρος -ροοῦντος Thphr. Vent. 10.
flow back, of perspiration, Diocl. Fr. 147.

back-rushing, refluent, π. δέ μιν αὖτις πλῆξεν [τὸ κῦμα] Od. 5.430; ἤπειρόνδε π. φέρε κῦμα, of the wave caused by the rock thrown by the Cyclops, 9.485; πενίης κῦμα π. Luc. Epigr. 2.12: generally, = παλίρροος, ναῦς π. Arat. 347; τὰ π., = παλίρροια, A.R. 1.1170.

definition: παλίρροια (also πᾰλιρροίᾱ S. Fr. 832), Ion. πᾰλιρρ-οίη, ἡ,

children.definition: flowing back, backwater, δίνας τινὰς . . ἰσχυρὰς καὶ παλιρροίην Hdt. 2.28; παλιρροία βυθοῦ, of the tide, S. l.c.; παλιρροίῃ ἐπινήχεται, of Delos, Call. Del. 193: in pl., Agathem. 5.22.
reflux, ἡ π. τῆς ὑγρότητος, in the spleen, Arist. PA 670b8; τοῦ θερμοῦ Id. Insomn. 461a6; ἐς π. ἰέναι Aret. CA 1.7.
παράδοξος π. τῶν πραγμάτων, of fortune, Plb. 1.82.3; ἡ ἐπʼ ἀμφότερα τὰ μέρη τῆς τύχης π. D.S. 18.59; also of ἀνάμνησις, Ph. 1.593.

data.quote: ἡ ἐπʼ ἀμφότερα τὰ μέρη τῆς τύχης π.

children.definition: dashing back with a roar, Opp. H. 5.220 ( v.l. πᾰλίρ-ροιζος).
= sq., of waves, δῖναι Lyc. 380, Opp. H. 1.778.
back-flowing, refluent, κλύδων E. IT 1397; ebbing and flowing, metaph., of the breath, ἀήρ Opp. H. 2.398; ἄσθμα Tryph. 76.

children.label: II
children.definition: recurring, returning upon oneʼs head, πότμος E. HF 739 (lyr.), cf. El. 1155 (lyr.).
tottering, bent, π. γόνυ (of an old man) E. El. 492.
roaring with ebb and flow, of Aulis, prob. in A. Ag. 190 (lyr., restd. metri gr. for παλιρρόθοις).
rush backwards, back-flow, τοῦ σάλου Plu. Flam. 10; π. τύχης a reverse of fortune, Plb. 15.7.1, D.S. 3.51 (mostly and perh. rightly written divisim in codd.).
flowing in retribution, prob. for πολύρρυτον in S. El. 1420 (lyr.); π. παγαί, of honey, dub. in Philox. 3.8 ( μελιρρύτοισι Mein.).
dragged back, Corp.Herm. 10.8 (v.l. -συτος).
rush quickly back, of waves, D.S. 1.32, 3.22.
rushing back, π. δράμημα hurried flight, S. OT 193 (lyr.); π. στεῖχε E. Supp. 388; ὁρμῆσαι Plb. 15.12.2, cf. παλίσσυρτος; χολή Aret. SD 1.15; π. φύσις recovering, Id. CA 2.3.
to be stiff-necked, refractory, contumacious, PPetr. 3p.136 (iii B. C.).

pursuit in turn, when fugitives rally and turn on their pursuers, π. δὲ γένηται ἐκ νηῶν [ῑ metri gr.] Il. 12.71; ἄν τοι ἔπειτα π. παρὰ νηῶν αἰὲν ἐγὼ τεύχοιμι 15.69, cf. 601; opp. προΐωξις, Hes. Sc. 154: in late Prose, App. Mith. 49.

data.quote: ἄν τοι ἔπειτα π. παρὰ νηῶν αἰὲν ἐγὼ τεύχοιμι

children.definition: ball ( σφαῖρα ἐκ ποικίλων ναμάτων (fort. νημάτων) πεποιημένη Hsch.), read by Dionysodorus for σφαῖρα in Od. 6.115.

definition: πάλλαγμα, f.l. in A. Supp. 296, v. ἐμπάλαγμα.

children.definition: statue of Pallas, Hdt. 4.189, Ar. Ach. 547, Jahresh. 16 Beibl. 42 (iv B. C.), IG 2(2).1388.67, etc.; Π. ἐκάλουν τὰ βαλλόμενα εἰς γῆν ἐκ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ ἀγάλματα Pherecyd. 179 J.

data.quote: Π. ἐκάλουν τὰ βαλλόμενα εἰς γῆν ἐκ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ ἀγάλματα

children.label: II
children.definition: court of the ἐφέται at Athens, ἐπὶ Π. δώσεις δίκην Ar. Fr. 585, cf. Arist. Ath. 57.3, Paus. 1.28.8 sq.
concubinage, Is. 3.39 ( παλλακίδι codd.), Str. 17.1.46, Peripl.M.Rubr. 49.
to be a concubine, esp. for ritual purposes, Str. 17.1.46, BCH 7.276 ( Tralles): generally, τῷ Μιθριδάτῃ Str. 13.4.3:—more freq. in Med. and Pass.,
keep as a concubine, Hdt. 4.155.
Pass., to be a concubine, Plu. Them. 26; τινι to one, Id. Fab. 21, Art. 26.

Hdt. 1.135, cf. 84, 2.130, al., Ar. V. 1353, Antipho 1.14, Lex ap. D. 23.53, Lys. 1.31, Pl. Ion 538b, Lg. 841d, D. 59.122, LXX Jd. 19.1, etc.; μηδὲ π. μηδὲ παιδικὸν ἔχειν Mitteis Chr. 284.4 (ii B. C.). (Prop. young girl, Ael.Dion. Fr. 172; cf. πάλλαξ.)

definition: παλλακίδιον, τό, Dim. of παλλακίς, Plu. An seni 2.789b.

children.definition: son by a concubine, Sophr. 124.

definition: παλλάκιον [ ᾱ], τό, Dim. of πάλλαξ, Alcm. 92 (dub. l.), Pl. Com. 206, Ael.Dion. Fr. 172 (who rejects the form παλλήκιον), Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: Gloss.

concubine, opp. lawful wife ( ἄκοιτις), Il. 9.449, 452; ὠνητὴ π. Od. 14.203, cf. LXX Jb. 19.17, Heroph. ap. Sor. 2.53 (dub. l.), etc.; π. δούλη AP 3.3 (Inscr. Cyzic.); ἐκ προγόνων παλλακίδων, of ritual prostitution, BCH 7.276 ( Tralles).
AP 6.247 ( Phil.).

definition: Παλλάντιος λόφος, ὁ, the Palatine hill at Rome, Ael. VH 12.11, cf. D.H. 1.31, Paus. 8.43.1.

children.definition: youth, below the age of an ἔφηβος, Ael.Dion. Fr. 172: fem., girl, Gell. 4.3:—also πάλληξ, GDI 5704.7 ( Samos, iii/ii B. C.), Ar. Byz. ap. Ammon.p.37 V., Corn. ND 20, Hsch.
Pallas, epith. of Athena, Παλλὰς Ἀθηναίη Il. 1.200, etc.; later used alone, = Ἀθήνη, B. 5.92, Hdt. 5.77, IG 1(2).573, etc.
coin bearing the head of Pallas, Eub. 6 (pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: maiden-priestess, Str. 17.1.46, Eust. 1742.37.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pythag. name for five, Theol.Ar. 32. (Commonly deriv. from πάλλω, either as Brandisher of the spear, or παρὰ τὸ ἀναπεπάλθαι ἐκ τῆς κεφαλῆς τοῦ Διός, etc., Pl. Cra. 407a, EM 649.52, cf. Eust. 84.43, but prob. orig. virgin, maiden, cf. sq. [πάλλας] and v. παλλακή fin., πάλλαξ.)
youth, Philist. 1 J.

definition: Παλλειών, ῶνος, ὁ, name of month at Magnesia on the Maeander, Inscr.Magn. 2.3 (iv/iii B. C.).

children.definition: all-white, A. Eu. 352 (lyr.); δέρη, πούς, E. Med. 30, 1164:—written πάνλευκος, Orac. ap. Phleg. Fr. 37 J. (restd. for ζάλευκος from Zos. 2.6), Nonn. D. 7.218.

definition: Παλλήνη, ἡ, a peninsula and town of Chalcidice, Hdt. 7.123, Th. 1.56, etc.; Maced. Βαλλήνη Eust. 1618.45 (whence the joke on Βαλλήναδε in Ar. Ach. 234, v. Sch. ad loc.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Παλληνεύς, ὁ, an inhabitant there of, Harp.; fem. Παλληνὶς Ἀθηναίη, Hdt. 1.62, cf. IG 1(2).310.189; Παλλήνᾰδε, to Pallene, v. supr. 1.

definition: παλλία, name of a contest, Hsch. (Prob. Lat. Palilia.)
παλλικάριον, τό (for παλληκ-, cf. παλλήκιον, πάλληξ),

children.definition: page, POxy. 1863.4.
BMus. Cat. Coins Ionia p.70 ( Ephesus):—also written παλυρριν, Num. Chron. 8(1908).282 (ibid.).

definition: πάλλω, impf. ἔπαλλον E. Hec. 1158; Ep. πάλλον always in Hom. (v. infr.): aor. 1 ἔπηλα S. El. 710; Ep. πῆλα Il. 6.474: Ep. aor. 2 part. πεπᾰλών Hom. only in compd. ἀμπεπαλών:— Med., aor. 1 πήλασθαι Call. Jov. 64: πεπάλασθε, πεπαλάσθαι (v. παλάσσω) have been attributed to πάλλω; πεπάλεσθε, πεπαλέσθαι are conjectured as more prob. forms:— Pass., pf. πέπαλμαι A. Ch. 410 (lyr.): aor. 2 ἐπάλην ( ἀν-) Str. 8.6.21: Ep. aor. πάλτο Il. 15.645 (in 13.643, 21.140, ἐπᾶλτο is from ἐφάλλομαι):—

children.definition: poise, sway a missile before it is thrown, τὸ μὲν [ἔγχος] οὐ δύνατʼ ἄλλος Ἀχαιῶν πάλλειν, ἀλλά μιν οἶος ἐπίστατο πῆλαι Ἀχιλλεύς Il. 16.142; [ αἰχμήν], ἣν . . πάλλεν δεξιτερῇ 22.320; δοῦρε δύω . . πάλλων 3.19; χερμάδιον . . ὃ οὐ δύο γʼ ἄνδρε φέροιεν . . , ὁ δέ μιν ῥέα πάλλε καὶ οἶος 5.304; ἄκοντα, λόγχην π., Pi. N. 3.45, E. IT 824; κεραυνόν Ar. Av. 1714.

data.quote: τὸ μὲν [ἔγχος] οὐ δύνατʼ ἄλλος Ἀχαιῶν πάλλειν, ἀλλά μιν οἶος ἐπίστατο πῆλαι Ἀχιλλεύς
χερμάδιον . . ὃ οὐ δύο γʼ ἄνδρε φέροιεν . . , ὁ δέ μιν ῥέα πάλλε καὶ οἶος

children.definition: sway, brandish, [ σάκος] Hes. Sc. 321; ἰτύν, πέλτας, E. Ion 210 (lyr.), Ba. 783; toss a child, πῆλε χερσίν, of Hector and Astyanax, Il. 6.474, cf. E. Hec. 1158; Νὺξ ὄχημʼ ἔπαλλεν she drove it furiously, Id. Ion 1151.

κλήρους ἐν κυνέῃ χαλκήρεϊ πάλλον shook the lots together in a helmet, Il. 3.316, cf. Od. 10.206; πάλλεν shook the lots, Il. 3.324, 7.181; but στάντες δʼ ὅθʼ αὐτοὺς οἱ . . βραβῆς κλήροις ἔπηλαν καὶ κατέστησαν δίφρους ranged them by casting lots, S. El. 710:— Med., draw lots, ἔλαχον πολιὴν ἅλα παλλομένων I obtained the white sea when we cast lots, Il. 15.191; παλλόμενος κλήρῳ λάχον ἐνθάδʼ ἕπεσθαι 24.400, cf. Hdt. 3.128:— Pass., κλῆρος οὐκ ἐπάλλετο S. Ant. 396.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., swing, dash oneself, ἐν ἄντυγι πάλτο tripped on the shield-rim, Il. 15.645; quiver, leap, esp. in fear, ἐν δʼ ἐμοὶ αὐτῇ στήθεσι πάλλεται ἦτορ 22.452; πέπαλταί μοι φίλον κέαρ A. Ch. 410; of the person, παλλομένη κραδίην Il. 22.461; δείματι παλλόμεναι, -οι, h.Cer. 293, Orac. ap. Hdt. 7.140, etc.; γόνυ πάλλεται γερόντων Ar. Ra. 345; of dying fish, quiver, leap, Hdt. 1.141, cf. 9.120; καὶ πέραν πόντοιο πάλλοντʼ αἰετοί fly quivering even beyond the sea, Pi. N. 5.21; vibrate, of strings, Pl. Phd. 94c ( ψάλλοιτο ap. Stob.); σκιρτητικὸν καὶ παλλόμενον τὸ νέον (etym. of Παλλάς) Corn. ND 20, cf. Pl. Cra. 407a.

data.quote: ἐν δʼ ἐμοὶ αὐτῇ στήθεσι πάλλεται ἦτορ

children.label: III
children.definition: leap, bound, E. El. 435, Ar. Lys. 1304 (lyr.); quiver, quake, φρένα δείματι πάλλων S. OT 153 (lyr.); dash along, of horses, E. El. 477 (lyr.).

definition: παλματίας, ου, ὁ, (πάλλω) σεισμὸς π. an earthquake

children.definition: with violent shocks, Arist. Mu. 396a10.
γέρρον (i. e. Lat. parma), Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: date, POxy. 519.18 (ii A. D.).
conveyed by palpitation, π. οἰώνισμα, title of a book, Suid. s.v. Ποσειδώνιος.

quivering motion, πυγῆς Alciphr. 1.39; esp. pulsation, throbbing (on π. and σφυγμός cf. Gal. 8.716), φλεβῶν Hp. Acut. 37; ὑποχονδρίου Id. Epid. 1.4.2 [1.26.βʹ]; ὑπὸ κροτάφοισι Nic. Al. 27, cf. Th. 744: abs., palpitation of the heart, a disease, Arist. Resp. 479b21; twitching, Gal. 7.588.
vibration, rapid motion, D.S. 3.51, Nonn. D. 2.193, al.; of meteors, Plu. Lys. 12 codd.; impetus of a projectile, Ath.Mech. 37.8.
Epicur., internal vibration of bodies, Ep. I p.8 U., cf. Id. ap. Placit. 1.12.5 (v.l. ἀποπαλμός).
= Lat. parmularius, M.Ant. 1.5.
Hippon. 1, 15; epith. of the king of the gods, Zeus, Lyc. 691: gen. πάλμυδος (Dind. for παλάμυδος) A. Fr. 437: acc. Πάλμυν pr. n. in Il. 13.792.
throbbing, palpitating, of persons, Hp. Prorrh. 1.30; ἰδέαι D.S. 3.50; π. νόσος Ph. 1.166; κινήσεις (opp. σφυγμώδεις) Gal. 8.722.
lot cast from a shaken helmet, A. Th. 458.

Ion., and Trag. generally, = κλῆρος, lot, τόνδε τὸν πάλον λαχόην Sapph. 9, cf. A. Th. 376; πάλῳ λαχεῖν ib. 126, Hdt. 4.94, 153, Aen.Tact. 20.2; πάλῳ ἀρχὰς ἄρχειν Hdt. 3.80; πάλου κύρσαι A. Pers. 779; τύχης π. Id. Ag. 333; οὓς ἐκλήρωσεν π. E. Ion 416, cf. S. Ant. 275, dub. in E. IA 1151.
ballot, vote, A. Eu. 742, 753.
= Lat. pālus, stake, PLond. 2.191.12 (ii A. D.), Aesop. 402, Edict.Diocl. 14.1, Zos. 2.35.

children.label: II
children.definition: squad or team of gladiators, CIG 2663 (Halic.), Rev.Arch. 30(1929).40 ( Aphrodisias), etc.

definition: πάλσαμον, τό, dial. form of βάλσαμον, Paus. 9.28.3.

children.definition: rapid motion, vibration, ἀκτίνων Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.11; in Epicur., = παλμός, internal vibration, Ep. 1 p. 12 U.
brandishing, δοράτων EM 394.56; palpitation, τῆς καρδίας Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.247.
throw a dart, in aor. 1 ἐπάλταξα, Hsch.

definition: παλτάρια σεμίδαλις, Phot., Suid.; cf. πολτάριον.

children.definition: scutch flax, BGU 1506.2.
brandished, hurled, πῦρ S. Ant. 131 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. παλτόν, τό, missile, dart, A. Fr. 16; of a light spear used by the Persian cavalry, X. Cyr. 4.3.9, 6.2.16, cf. Arr. Fr. 158 J.; projectile discharged from a catapult, Id. Tact. 43.1.
strew, sprinkle, λεύκʼ ἄλφιτα πολλὰ πάλυνον ( i.e. sprinkled in water, expld. by Sch. ἔμασσον, ἔφυρον) Il. 18.560; ἐπὶ δʼ ἄλφιτα λευκὰ παλύνειν Od. 10.520, cf. 11.28, etc.; τι ἐπί τινι S. Ant. 247.

children.label: II
children.definition: bestrew, besprinkle, with dat. of the thing sprinkled, παλύνας ἀλφίτου ἀκτῇ Od. 14.429:— Pass., ἁ σῦριγξ εὐρῶτι παλύνεται Theoc. 4.28.
κάρην ἱδρῶτι παλῦναι D.P. 1049.
besmear, ἰξῷ AP 10.11 ( Satyr.), cf. A.R. 3.1256 ( Pass.).

children.label: III
children.definition: cover lightly, χιὼν ἐπάλυνεν ἀρούρας Il. 10.7; νιφετῷ δʼ ἐπαλύνετο πάντα A.R. 3.69.

property, Schwyzer 657.39 ( Tegea, iv B. C.), Theoc. Syrinx 12 (v.l. πῆμα): mostly pl., πατρῷα καὶ ματρῷα π. Schwyzer l.c. 6, cf. 27, Besant. Ara 5, AJP 26.463 ( Argos); of cattle, SIG 527.89 ( Dreros, iii B. C.).
confiscate, IG 9(1).334.41 ( Locr., v B. C., Pass.).
absolute monarchy, Arist. Pol. 1285b36, 1287a8.
queen of all, all-powerful queen, Ar. Nu. 357, 1150, A.R. 4.382; of Persephone, IG 12(5).310.15 ( Paros).
absolute monarch, Alc. 5, LXX Si. 50.15 ( 17); of Hadrian, Epigr.Gr. 990.3 ( Balbilla).
utterly abominable, Ar. Lys. 969, Ec. 1043.
all-subduing, κεραυνός Pi. N. 9.24.
wholly hurtful, Man. 4.31.

definition: Παμβοιώτιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of a month in Boeotia, IG 7.3321.

children.label: II
children.definition: Παμβοιώτια (sc. ἱερά), τά, festival of the United Boeotians, Plb. 4.3.5, 9.34.11, IG 7.3087 ( Lebadea), Str. 9.2.29.
United Boeotians, IG 7.2712.49 (Acraeph.).
all-devouring, J. AJ 5.8.6, Ael. NA 1.27 ( Sup.).
all the herbage, τοῦ ἀγροῦ LXX Jb. 5.25.
all-nourishing, ἄλσος A. Supp. 558 (lyr.), cf. Fr. 99.
= foreg., Cypr. 1.4:—fem. παμ-βῶτις, ιδος, Γᾶ S. Ph. 391 (lyr.).
all-blissful, Orph. H. 19.3, Hsch.
= foreg., JHS 22.97 ( Pisidia), Hsch. s.v. πανόλβιος.
all-vain, A. Ag. 388 codd. (leg. πᾶν μ.).
in which all fight, A.D. Conj. 234.9.
contests of all kinds, B. 12.76.
Phot., Suid.

ready or sufficient for every battle, θράσος A. Ag. 169 (lyr.); epith. of Athena, Ar. Lys. 1321; esp. = παγκρατιαστής, fighting by all means, with all oneʼs resources, Pl. Euthd. 271c, Theoc. 24.114, APl. 16.52 ( Phil.), D.Chr. 8.19; τοὺς πέντε προεκαλεσάμην πάμμαχα Sammelb. 6222.22 (iii A. D.); so εἰς τὸ πάμμαχον ib. 26; ὁ παμμάχων κεραυνός AP 7.692 (Antip. or Phil.): metaph., οὐ φαῦλος ἀλλὰ π. ἀγὼν ὁ τῆς πολιτείας calling for all resources, Plu. Praec. 2.804b; also π: ἀτυχίη incompetence ready for anything, Hp. Praec. 13.
very great, immense, Pl. Phdr. 273a, Ti. 26e, etc.: Sup. παμμέγιστος Ael. VH 10.2.
= foreg., Pl. Prm. 164d, Lg. 913d, X. Mem. 3.6.13, Timocl. 8.14, D. 19.241, Arist. GA 745a34, al., Men. Her. 2: neut. as Adv., παμμέγεθες ἀναβοᾶν Aeschin. 2.106, cf. Men. Sam. 149.
exceeding mild, Jo.Gaz. Ecphr. 1.75.
all-black, ταῦροι Od. 3.6; ὄϊς 11.33; τράγος IG 2(2).1358 (iv B. C.); βόες Ael. NA 15.14.

definition: παμμελεί, Adv. of παμμελής II, Porph. Chr. 94.

children.definition: in all kinds of melodies, ὕμνοι LXX 3 Ma. 7.16.

children.label: II
children.definition: with all the limbs, entire, ἱερεῖα Poll. 1.29.
quite covered with, ὄρος π. τερμίνθων Thphr. HP 3.15.3.
in all kinds of metres, D.L. 7.31.
very long, prolonged, γόοι S. OC 1609; λόγος Pl. Plt. 286e; ῥήσεις Id. Phdr. 268c; ἐν χρόνοις π. Arist. Mete. 351b10: neut. as Adv., πάμμηκες διαφέρει ἔπαινος ἡδονῆς Max.Tyr. 7.7 [1.7.a].
lighted by the full moon, Arat. 189.
through all months, through the live-long year, S. El. 851 (lyr.).
π. σελήνη, = πανσέληνος, ἡ, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.936a, Doroth. ap. Heph.Astr. 3.9; at full moon, ἱκετεῖαι cj. in Philod. Scarph. 114 ( BCH 49.130).
all-inventive, μοῖρα βροτῶν Lyc. 490; Ἄρης Trag.Adesp. 129.9 (lyr.); Μοῖρα Orph. Fr. 47.
h.Hom. 30.1, AP 5.164 ( Mel.), v.l. in Orph. Fr. 168.27.
all-knowing, all-planning, θεός Simon. 61.
mother of all, γῆ A. Pr. 90, Ph. 1.32, cf. Orph. Fr. 168.27; θεᾷ παμμήτορι Ῥείῃ Epigr.Gr. 823.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: a very mother, γυνὴ τοῦδε π. νεκροῦ S. Ant. 1282.
all-abominable, Ar. Pax 183, Ra. 466, LXX 4 Ma. 10.17 ( Sup.).
mixed of all sorts, all-blended, βέλεα A. Pers. 269 (lyr.); στρατός Tim. Pers. 188; ἔθνη LXX 2 Ma. 12.13; σύμμαχοι D.S. 29.19; βοή Lyc. 5.
very small, Arist. PA 665b1, 669b29, Po. 1450b37, Gal. 18(2).753.
A. Pers. 53 (anap.); ἐπίκουροι ib. 903 (lyr.), cf. Aq. Ps. 77(78).45, Vett.Val. 15.15.
all-hapless, S. OC 161 (lyr.).
assuming all forms, of Proteus, Theol.Ar. 7; ἰδέαι Dam. Pr. 311.
all-musical, ἁρμονία, χορεία, Ph. 1.625, 526; ἀνήρ Calder Philadelphia and Montanism 35.
all-countless, Ph. 1.329.
Ar. Lys. 969.
all-remembering, πραπίδες Maiist. 46.
wholly passive, Plot. 1.8.3; ὕλη Iamb. Myst. 3.29.
with all their children, D.C. 41.9; cf. παγγυναικί.
very old, Pl. Tht. 181b, Arist. Metaph. 1074b1, cj. in ib. 983b28; opp. καινός, Plu. Cat.Ma. 1.
altogether to the contrary, Crates Com. 15.
possessing all, Hsch. (cj. for Πάμπανον).

wholly, altogether, with Verb, Il. 1.422, Od. 2.49, Hes. Op. 275, 302, Sapph. 51.4, Pi. O. 2.69, Emp. 140: with Adj., π. ὀϊζυρός Od. 20.140, cf. E. Med. 1091 (anap.); οὐ π. ἀληθέες Call. Jov. 60: with Adv., π. ἐτήτυμον Il. 13.111: preceded by a neg., οὐδέ τι πάμπαν not at all, by no means, 9.435, cf. 21.338: with the Art., τὸ π. E. Rh. 855, Fr. 196: rare in early Prose, Hdt. 2.45, X. Ages. 11.4, Aen. Tact. 16.2; τὸ π. Pl. Plt. 270e, Ti. 41b: freq. in Arist., as Cael. 286a6, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., πάμπαν τὸ λοιπόν IG 1(2).6.117.

definition: πάμπανυ, Adv. strengthd. for πάνυ, dub. in D.C. 56.30.

children.definition: all-persuasive, Pi. P. 4.184.
entirely, Thgn. 615, A. Pers. 729 (troch.), Fr. 156, S. Aj. 916:—also παμ-πηδόν, παμ-ονίς, Theognost. Can. 163.
entire possession, full property, A. Th. 817, E. Ion 1305, Ar. Ec. 868.
in large quantity, number, χρήματα Hdn. 5.6.5; ἄργυρος Ael. NA 10.50; πάμπλειστα δαπανήσας D.C. 76.16.
much greater, ὄγκος τῆς φωνῆς Arist. Aud. 804a15.

definition: παμπλήγδην, Adv. strengthd. for ἐμπλήγδην, Suid.

children.definition: with the whole multitude, Ev.Luc. 23.18, D.C. 75.9.
in or with their whole multitude, παμπληθεῖς Ἀρκάδες X. HG 6.5.26.

children.label: II
children.definition: very numerous, multitudinous, μεταβολαί Pl. Lg. 782b, cf. Tht. 156b; γεωργίαι D. 19.145; πονηρίαι Id. 21.19; χρήματα prob. in D.S. 14.13; κραυγαί POxy. 1242.54 (i A. D.): c. gen., παμπληθεῖς Ἀργείων Isoc. 12.169: with sg., π. ἂν τὸ γένος ἦν (sc. τῶν ἰχθύων) Arist. HA 567b2; π. κεκτήμεθα τὴν οὐσίαν a vast amount of . . , Isoc. 15.154; πῦρ π. Arist. Mir. 833a20.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv., entirely, παμπληθὲς ἀπέσχεν D. 19.19, cf. D.C. 55.20.
multitude, οἰκετῶν S. Fr. 373.4.
Abh.Berl.Akad. 1909 (2).62.
to be plentiful, Aq. Jb. 36.31.
in which blows fall thick, S. Tr. 505 (lyr.).
quite full, Arist. GC 325a29 (v.l. -πληθές).
very rich, Pl. Lg. 743c, D.C. 40.12.
= foreg., ὄλβος S. Fr. 646.5; π. ἐν πλούτῳ γενέσθαι Gal. Anim.Pass. 9.

all-variegated, of rich and varied work, πέπλοι Od. 15.105, cf. Il. 6.289; of sacred vases, Pi. N. 10.36; νεβρῶν π. στολίδες E. Hel. 1359 (lyr.); of persons, π. περὶ πᾶσαν τέχνην καὶ πρᾶξιν Vett.Val. 17.16.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὕφασμα, of the universe, Ph. 1.651, cf. 654; manifold, ἀλλοιότητας παμποικίλους ( παμποικίλας codd.) Pl. Ti. 82b.
prevailing in all cities, universal, νόμος dub. in S. Ant. 614 (lyr., πάμπολύ γʼ Heath).

very great, large, or numerous, κατάγελως Ar. Eq. 320; γῆς πλῆθος Pl. Lg. 677e; στράτευμα X. An. 2.4.26; τύχη Pl. Lg. 640d (but πάμπολλος as fem., Luc. Cyn. 1, Ael. VH 4.8, A.D. Pron. 89.12, Synt. 36.27): in pl., very many, Ar. Pax 694, Pl. R. 373c, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: πάμπολυ, as Adv., very much, Id. Sph. 255d, etc.; cf. foreg.
thoroughly depraved, Ar. Ach. 854, Nu. 1319, Pl. R. 489d, D. 18.119, Phld. Rh. 1.344S.
very bad, ὄψον Epich. 87; διάθεσις Phld. Ir. p.77 W.
Adv. -ρως, ἔχειν to be very ill, Luc. Abd. 14, cf. Jul. Or. 8.241b.
all-destroying, prob. for παμπρόσθη in A. Ag. 714 (lyr.).
all-purple, Pi. O. 6.55.
all-venerable, AP 6.281 ( Leon.).
unreserved sale of property, Poll. 7.196, al.
all-conspicuous, ἕδραι A. Ag. 117 (lyr.).
all face, χρῆμα Plot. 6.7.15.
lord of all, Ph. 1.642.
the very first, first of all, Il. 7.324, 9.93: neut. πάμπρωτον as Adv., Od. 4.577; ἐπεὶ π. εἶδον φέγγος Pi. P. 4.111: also in pl. -πρωτα, Il. 4.97, 17.568: Sup. παμπρώτιστα A.R. 4.1693.
full of pus, πτύσιες Hp. Coac. 373.
very miserable, Arch.Pap. 1.428 (iv A. D.).
all-devouring, voracious, ὁ π. Ἀλκμάν Alcm. 33.4; πῦρ E. Med. 1187.

children.label: II
children.definition: omnivorous, ζῷα (opp. ζῳοφάγα, καρποφάγα) Arist. Pol. 1256a25, cf. HA 488a15, 593b25; τῶν π., οἷς πάντα ἐσθίειν νόμος Jul. Or. 6.192d: Comp., τὰ -ώτερα ποικιλώτερα Arist. GA 786a34: Sup., -ώτατον πάντων ὁ βοῦς Thphr. HP 9.15.4.

data.quote: τῶν π., οἷς πάντα ἐσθίειν νόμος

children.definition: all-shining, radiant, of fire, S. Ph. 728 (lyr.) E. Tr. 548 (lyr.); of the sun, Id. Med. 1251 (lyr.), cf. Ar. Av. 1709, IG 12(5).891.3 ( Tenos), etc.; of honey, bright, pure, A. Pers. 612.

definition: παμφαίνω, only pres. and impf. ( παμφαίνεσκε Eratosth. 17),

children.definition: shine or beam brightly, of burnished metal (cf. παμφανόων) , ἧλοι χρύσειοι πάμφαινον Il. 11.30; σάκος χαλκῷ παμφαῖνον 14.11; τεύχεσι παμφαίνων, of Achilles, 19.398; of a star, ὅς τε μάλιστα λαμπρὸν παμφαίνησι or -ῃσι ( Ep. for παμφαίνει or -ῃ) 5.6; πρῶτον παμφαίνων Hes. Op. 567; στήθεσι παμφαίνοντες with their breasts white-gleaming, i. e. naked, Il. 11.100; ὕπερθε κέρα πάμφαινεν ἰδέσθαι Epic. in Arch.Pap. 7.3: cited as a recondite word by Phld. Po. 2.40. (Redupl. form of φαίνω.)

definition: παμφαλάω, redupl. form like παιφάσσω (cf. παπταλάω, παπταίνω),

children.definition: gaze in astonishment, Ion. word, Hippon. 131, Anacr. 160, Herod. 4.77; πάντοσε παμφαλόωντες Eryc. ap. Sch. A.R. 2.127: aor. 1 ἐπαμφάλησα· ἐθαύμασα, Hsch.:— Med., ἄγχι παμφαλώμενος Lyc. 1433.
Hsch.

definition: παμφανόων, gen. ωντος, fem. παμφᾰνόωσα, Ep. part. as if from παμφᾰνάω (cf. παμφανάα· λάμπει, Hsch.),

children.definition: bright-shining, radiant, of burnished metal, αἴγλη [χαλκοῦ] Il. 2.458; τεύχεα 5.295, 18.144; ἠέλιος Od. 13.29; αἰθήρ Emp. 98.2.
skilled in all charms or drugs, of Medea, Pi. P. 4.233.
S. El. 105 (lyr.).
all-bearing, all-including, Gal. 19.469.
all-speaking, Zonar.
all-destroying, μόρος A. Ch. 296.
destroyer of all, στάσις B. Fr. 20.2.
with or of all sounds, Hsch.
Hsch.
beloved of all, ὄλβος prob. in A. Eu. 536 (lyr.): Sup. -έστατος PGrenf. 2.92.11 (vi A. D.).
all-blazing, βωμοί S. Ant. 1006; π. πῦρ Id. El. 1139, Axionic. 4.11.
very dreadful, Tab.Defix.Aud. 38.11 ( Alexandria, iii A. D.), Gloss.
all-feeding, παλάμη AP 7.698 (Christod.), cf. Epigr.Gr. 1036 (Nicomedia, dub.), Eust. 978.4.
all-bearing, all-productive, χώρη παμφορωτέρη Hdt. 7.8.αʹ, cf. Hp. Coac. 502, Pl. Lg. 704c, Thphr. HP 3.2.6; γαῖα A. Pers. 618; ἔτος Orph. Fr. 251; παμφορώτατον κτῆμα ὃ καλεῖται φίλος X. Mem. 2.4.7.

children.label: II
children.definition: bearing all things with it, π. χέραδος a mixed mass of rubbish, Pi. P. 6.13: metaph., π. θεωρήματα Pall. in Hp. 2.114 D.
wise in all things, Tz. H. 6.595 ( Sup.).
in total rout, Opp. H. 2.548 (v.l. παμφύρδην).
combining all natures, δέμας, of Pan, IG 42(1).130.19 (Epid.).
President of the Provincial Council of Pamphylia, BCH 23.302 ( Termessus), IGRom. 3.474 ( Balbura).
of mingled tribes or races, γένος Pl. Plt. 291a; πόλις Poll. 9.21; π. θῆρες Ar. Av. 1063.

children.label: II
children.definition: Πάμφυλοι, οἱ, one of the three Dorian tribes, Hdt. 5.68, IG 42(1).71.49 (Epid.), SIG 1025.8 ( Cos), etc.: gen. pl. Παμφυλᾶν IG 4.598 ( Argos); Παμφύλεων SIG 1027.4 (Cos.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Pamphylian, Hdt. 1.28, al., Pl. R. 614b, etc.
mixed of all sorts, γέννημα Ph. 1.148, cf. 2.53, Longin. 9.7, Opp. H. 1.779: neut. pl. as Adv., confusedly, S. Ichn. 232.

with all tones, full-toned or many-toned, ἔντεα αὐλῶν Pi. O. 7.12; μέλος Id. P. 12.19; αὐλῶν ὁμοκλαί Id. I. 5(4).27; ὑμέναιοι Id. P. 3.17: generally, expressive, χεῖρες APl. 16.290 (Antip.); π. οἶνος noisy, Philox. 16.
much-blamed, Man. 4.316.
one that blames all, Man. 4.58.
with all the votes, π. νικᾶν AP 11.239 ( Lucill.), cf. Sch. Ar. Eq. 525, etc.; Dor. παμ-ψᾱφεί Polus ap. Stob. 3.9.51.
Ptol. Tetr. 160.
in full life, π. ἀνάσσει, of Amphiaraus, S. El. 841 (lyr., also expld. by Sch. as ‘ruling over all the shades’ or ‘immortal’, = πασῶν ψυχῶν ἀνάσσει, cf. Od. 11.483 sq., A. Ch. 355).
own, possess, Tab. Heracl. 1.168:—also πᾱμ-ωχιῶν· κεκτημένος, Hsch.; and πᾱμ-ῶχος, ὁ, Dor. for παμοῦχος, owner, Id.
fish, Ptol.Chenn. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.153 B., Suid. s.h.v. (Cf. Egypt. p-ān ‘Nile perch, Tilapia nilotica’.)

definition: Πάν, gen. Πᾱνός, dat. Πᾱνί (un contr. Πάονι IG 5(2).556 ( Melpea, vi B. C.)), ὁ,

children.definition: Pan, Πᾶνα δέ μιν καλέεσκον, ὅτι φρένα πᾶσιν ἔτερψεν h.Hom. 19.47, cf. 5, Hdt. 2.145, 6.105, etc.; ὦ Πὰν Ἀρκαδίας μεδέων Pi. Fr. 95, cf. Theoc. 1.123, etc.; Π. κεροβάτας Ar. Ra. 230 (lyr.): pl. Πᾶνες Id. Ec. 1069, Theoc. 4.63, D.S. 1.88; dat. pl. Πᾶσιν Id. 5.28; Πανὸς γόνος, σπέρμα, in magic, PMag.Par. 1.2306, 2996; Πανὸς κέρατα, = γλυκυσίδη, Ps.- Dsc. 3.140.

data.quote: Πᾶνα δέ μιν καλέεσκον, ὅτι φρένα πᾶσιν ἔτερψεν

children.definition: quite or very soft, Luc. Rh.Pr. 11.
perfect goodness, Theag. ap. Stob. 3.1.117.

definition: πανάγαθος [ ᾰγ], ον, also η, ον,

children.definition: absolutely good, Cratin. 434, Pl. Ep. 354e, Simp. in Epict. p.76 D.

all-hallowed, Call. Fr. 1.36P.; κόρη ( Cassandra) D.Chr. 11.153; ἱέρειαι Poll. 1.35, Hsch. ( παναιεῖς cod.); ἱερωσύνη Jul. Or. 5.160b ( Sup.); ἱερεύς IG 3.716; = Lat. sacrosanctus, of the Rom. Tribuni Plebis, D.H. 6.89, 8.87, Plu. Cam. 20.

children.label: II
children.definition: under an ἄγος, Philonid. 5, Man. 4.120.
most reverend, Man. 2.433.
all-holy, LXX 4 Ma. 7.4.
Hsch.
ὄμμα Callistr. Stat. 10; κήρυκες Sch. Aeschin. 1.20.
Schwyzer 657.21 ( Tegea, iv B. C., pl.).
taking all kinds of game, νευρά AP 6.75 ( Paul.Sil.).
one who catches everything, παναγρέος ἐλπίδα Μοίρης AP 7.609 ( Paul.Sil.); φυλάκων . . παναγρέα κανθόν ib. 5.218 ( Id.).
quite wild or savage, Opp. C. 2.45, dub. in Ps.-Phoc. 202.

definition: παναγρίς, ίδος, ἡ, = λεβητάριον, IG 4.1588.18 ( Aegina), Poll. 10.165 (v.l. ταναγρίς).

children.definition: fishing- or hunting-net, Opp. C. 1.150, H. 3.83.

children.label: II
children.definition: large hen-coop in which fowls are fattened, Ath. 1.22d.
catching all, λίνον π., of a large fishing-net, Il. 5.487; δίκτυον Ath. 1.25b: metaph., λίνῳ θανάτοιο π. Tryph. 674.
all-wakeful, μέριμνα AP 7.195 ( Mel.).

definition: παναγυριάρχας, παν-αγύριος, παν-άγυρις, v. πανηγυριάρχης, πανηγύριος, πανήγυρις.

children.definition: passing through all trials, epith. of martyrs, PMasp. 162.8 (vi A. D.).
cruel, μοῖραι Epigr.Gr. 403.1; μόχθος Antioch. Astr. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.112.
all-undigested, δόρπος Nic. Al. 66.
unarmed, ὤμοσαν ἀγελάοι π. SIG 527.11 ( Crete, iii B. C.).
utterly lawless, cj. for sq. in Man. 4.56.
quite inexorable, Hsch. ( παναίθετος cod.).

Panathenaea, festival at Athens, Hdt. 5.56; τὰ μεγάλα Π. Th. 5.47, Lys. 21.1, Isoc. 12.17, IG 1(2).10.2, 304.6; τὰ μικρὰ Π. Lys. 21.2 (also τὰ κατʼ ἐνιαυτόν IG 2(2).334.32), cf. Ar. Nu. 988, And. 1.28, etc.; also at Ilium, festival of Athena Ilias, SIG 355.18 (iv/iii B. C.).
of, for, or at the Panathenaea, ἡ Π. πομπή Th. 1.20, etc.; ὁ Π. (sc. λόγος), name of a speech of Isocrates: τὰ π. name of vases given as prizes at the P., Posidon. 25 J.

definition: Παναθήναιος, ὁ (sc. μήν), month at Ilium, Supp.Epigr. 4.663.

children.definition: period between celebrations of the Great Panathenaea, IG 3.1202.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., Παναθηναῒς σκάφη ship borne in procession at the Panathenaea, SIG 894 (iii A. D.).
celebrators of Παναθήναια, at Teos, CIG 3073; at Rhodes, IG 12(1).107, al.
all-wretched, A. Ch. 695, S. OC 1110, E. Hec. 658, Timocl. 25: in late Prose, Ph. 1.542.
all-shining, κῆπος AP 9.806.
all-revered, Epigr. Gr. 228b ( Ephesus).
all-blazing, κόρυθες Il. 14.372.
shot with many colours, glancing, ζωστήρ 4.186, 215, 10.77; θώρηξ 11.374; σάκος 13.552, Hes. Sc. 139; star-spangled, π. οὐρανός Orph. H. 4.7, Fr. 238.

children.label: II
children.definition: manifold, βάγματα A. Pers. 636 (lyr.).
full vigour of the senses, D.L. 10.65 (Meibom for ἀναισθ-).
all-impious, Hsch. ( -αίγ- cod.).
utterly ugly, τὴν ἰδέαν Arist. EN 1099b4, cf. Poll. 6.163.
absolute ugliness, Tz. H. 3.216.
D.Chr. 31.35, Ptol. Tetr. 172: Sup., παναισχίστη τέρψις AP 6.163 ( Mel.). Adv. -ρως Plb. 4.58.11, Tz. H. 6.44.
cause of all, Ζεύς A. Ag. 1486; ἓν π. Dam. Pr. 37.
to whom all the guilt belongs, opp. μεταίτιος, A. Eu. 200.
meeting and festival of the Aetolian League, SIG 563 ( Teos, iii B. C.), IG 9(1).411;—also Πᾰναιτώλια, τά, Poll. 6.163:— also in sg., Liv. 31.29.
all-barren, Nic. Th. 612.
universal remedy, panacea, Longin. 38.5, Ph. 1.215, Gal. 13.766.
a healing herb or its juice (cf. πανακής II), Call. Ap. 40, etc.; πανακείας ῥίζα Gal. 14.156; Hercules’ woundwort, Opopanax hispidus, Thphr. HP 9.15.7.

children.label: b
children.definition: Laserpitium garganicum, Ps.- Dsc. 3.51.
Pythag. name for six, Theol. Ar. 38.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hp. Jusj. 1, Ar. Pl. 702, 730.

definition: πανάκειον [ ᾰκ], τό, = foreg. [πανάκεια] I.2, Nic. Th. 508.

children.definition: free from all care, σαύρη, of the salamander, prob. in Nic. Al. 538.
all-uncontaminated, θεός Corp.Herm. 18.12; Ἄπολλον PMag.Berol. 2.87.
all-healing, π. πάντων φάρμακον ἁ σοφία Call. Epigr. 47.4, cf. Ph. 1.455 ( Sup.); ποτάμιον π. πρὸς τὰς τῶν θρεμμάτων νόσους Str. 6.3.9; λύπης πανακές Epicur. Fr. 154.

data.quote: ποτάμιον π. πρὸς τὰς τῶν θρεμμάτων νόσους

children.label: II
children.definition: πάνακες, ους, τό, all-heal, Ferulago galbanifera, Hp. Mul. 2.201, Thphr. HP 9.7.2, etc.; π. Ἀσκληπίειον Aesculapius’ all-heal, Echinophora tenuifolia, ib. 9.8.7, 9.11.1; π. Ἡράκλειον, = πανάκεια 1.2a, ib. 9.11.3, Dsc. 3.48; π. Κενταύρειον Centaury, Centaurea salonitana, Plin. HN 25.33, Sch. Nic. Th. 564; π. λεπτόφυλλον feverfew, Erythraea Centaurium, Thphr. HP 9.11.4; π. Χειρώνειον elecampane, Inula Helenium, ib. 9.11.1; also, = Chironʼs all-heal, Hypericum olympicum, Nic. Th. 565 (cf. 500), Dsc. 3.50, Gal. 12.95.
prepared with πάνακες, Dsc. 5.62.

definition: πανάκτειος, ον, in Nic. Th. 626, π. κονίλη, expld. by Sch. either as ἡ ἐπὶ πάσῃ ἀκτῇ φυομένη or as a poet. form of πανάκειος; cf. πάνακτος· ὀρίγανος, Hsch.
παναλάστωρ, ορος, ὁ, strengthd. for ἀλάστωρ, AP 9.269 ( Antip. Thess.).

children.definition: all true, π. κακόμαντις Ἐρινύς A. Th. 722 (lyr.). Adv. -θῶς Id. Supp. 86 (lyr.).
absolutely true or real, ἡδονή Pl. R. 583b, cf. Iamb. Protr. 4 ( Sup.).
roving all about, ψυχή Procl. H. 3.15.
all-healing, Nic. Th. 939.
all-powerful, v.l. for παναρκής, A. Th. 166 (lyr.): Sup., of a poultice, Aët. 3.177 (sed cf. παναρκής).
all-purple-dyed, Xenoph. 3.3.
all-catching, ἄτη A. Ag. 361 (anap.).

definition: Πανάμαρος [νᾱ], title of Zeus in Caria, BCH 12.254, al., Supp.Epigr. 4.263.3, al. ( Panamara):—also Πανήμερος, ib. 288, al.; Πανημέριος, ib. 304, al. (ibid.): hence Παναμάρεια, τά, his festival, BCH 11.376. Supp.Epigr. 4.301.12 (ibid.).

children.definition: all-unsmiling, πρόσωπα Opp. C. 3.141.
all-implacable, δράκαινα Opp. C. 3.223.
all-unmerciful, ἦτορ Opp. C. 2.203.
without any share in, ἠελίοιο AP 14.125 ( Metrod.).

definition: Πάναμος [ πᾰ], ὁ, name of a month, at Argos, Mnemos. 44.51; at Epidaurus, IG (1).117.9, al.; at Megara, ib. 7.188; at Thespiae, ib. 1720:—also written Πάνεμος ( Boeot.), Plu. Cam. 19; Πάνημος, D. 18.157 (Corinth.), Call. Epigr. 46, IG ΙΙ(2).203 A 31 ( Delos, iii B. C.), PCair.Zen. 20.5 (iii B. C.):—hence Πανάμια, τά, festival at Thespiae, Schwyzer 491.11.

children.definition: all-blameless, Simon. 5.17.

definition: πανάνυτον παντοδύναμον, Phot.; πάντα δυνατόν, Suid.

children.definition: πανάκεια, Dsc. 2.163, 3.51, Ps.- Dsc. 3.48, Philagr. ap. Orib. 5.19.12, etc.
all-worthy, Opp. C. 3.408.
sung by all, APl. 16.71, Dioscorus in PLit.Lond. 100 C 6.
all-tender or delicate, ἀνδρὶ δέμας εἰκυῖα νέῳ . . , παναπάλῳ Od. 13.223 [ πᾱν-, metri gr.]; γυναῖκες Ph. 2.432.
without tasting, ἐδωδῆς Nic. Al. 592.
all-unbounded, Opp. C. 2.517.
= foreg., ὦ π. Κρονίων Pi. Pae. 8.24.

definition: παναπενθής, ές, f.l. for ταλαπενθής, APl. 16.265.

children.definition: utterly inscrutable, ἀταρπός Parm. 4.6.
all-harmless, Hes. Op. 811; of Apollo, AP 9.525.17.
all-unmutilated, κεφαλαί Call. Cer. 126.
all-untrustworthy, Phld. Rh. 1.232 S. ( Sup.).
all-astounded, Socr. Ep. 36.
Hsch. gives it as a gloss), Ascl. in Metaph. 421.29.
entirely opposite, οἶμος (of heavenly bodies) Man. 6.295.
all-hapless, ὤ μοι ἐγὼ πανάποτμος Il. 24.255, cf. 493.
all-unheard of, Phot., Suid., restd. in Philic. in Stud.Ital. 9.48.
all-silver, κρητήρ Od. 9.203, 24.275, Antim. 15, cf. S. Fr. 378.3.
all-heroic, in pl., Dioscorus in PLit.Lond. 99.9.
model of all virtue, Phld. Rh. 2.203S., Ph. 1.451, Luc. Philops. 6, S.E. M. 9.152, IG 14.2098, CIG 4413 ( Iotape); also ἡ π. σου φιλία PSI 1.98.3 (vi A. D.). Adv. -τως CIG 4150 ( Amastris).

children.label: II
children.definition: πανάρετος, ἡ, a Book of Fortunes, Paul.Al. K. 2.
wholly enviable, Ἀριάδνη Dioscorus in PLit.Lond. 99.4.
= Lat. panarium (Gr. ἀρτοφόριον), S.E. M. 1.234.
best of all, Hes. Op. 293, Phld. Rh. 2.198 S., AP 11.394, Luc. Fug. 30.
self-sufficiency, etym. of πανάκεια I.3, Theol.Ar. 38.
utter, complete, dub. in A. Ch. 70 (lyr.).
A. Th. 166 (lyr.); Ἠέλιος the sun that shines on all alike, Call. Fr. 48.1, cf. Suid. s.v.: Sup., of a poultice, Lycus ap. Orib. 9.26.1; cf. παναλκής.

embracing all modes or scales, in neut. of a style of Music, οὐκ ἄρα πολυχορδίας γε οὐδὲ παναρμονίου ἡμῖν δεήσει ἐν ταῖς ᾠδαῖς τε καὶ μέλεσι Pl. R. 399c, cf. 404d; [ ὄργανα] π. ib. 399d; αὐτὰ τὰ π. ibid.; τὸ π. τὸ καινόν Alex. 298; π. ὄργανον D.C. 74.3.

data.quote: οὐκ ἄρα πολυχορδίας γε οὐδὲ παναρμονίου ἡμῖν δεήσει ἐν ταῖς ᾠδαῖς τε καὶ μέλεσι

children.label: II
children.definition: complex, elaborate, ποικίλῃ μὲν ποικίλους ψυχῇ καὶ π. διδοὺς λόγους opp. ἁπλοῦς, Pl. Phdr. 277c, cf. Iamb. Myst. 5.21; π. τι χρῆμα ἡ ὄρχησις Luc. Salt. 72; ψυχαὶ π. διὸ παντοδαπῶς ἔστιν ἀκούειν ἀμφοτέρων, of Homer and Plato, Olymp. Vit.Pl. p.4 W.

harmonious, χορός Ph. 2.399; ἀστέρων στρατιά ib. 242; συζυγία τῶν τεττάρων δυνάμεων ib. 136; ἑβδομάς, ὀγδοάς, ib. 166, Pythag. ap. Theol.Ar. 54; τετράχορδον, of Diocletian and his associates, Jul. Caes. 315c; π. ἐρωαί, of the song of the Muses, Orac. ap. Porph. Plot. 22: neut. as Adv., π. ᾄδειν Philostr. Im. 2.1.
extremely ancient, πίναξ Chron.Lind. B. 88.
= foreg., γράμματα Poll. 5.150.
all-powerful, ruling all, θρόνοι S. OC 1293.
ruler of all, Ph. 2.452 (pl.).
all-unharmed, Hsch.
very readily, only in Sup. -έστατα Tz. H. 9.10.
giving security, epith. of Zeus and Poseidon at Mytilene, Ath.Mitt. 24.358 (Mytil.).
all-exact, infallible, φάτις Keil-Premerstein Erster Bericht p.9 ( Troketta); μνῆμα AP 7.594 ( Jul.): neut. as Adv., A.R. 4.1382.
fount of light, Ph. 1.7.
all-bright, radiant, Orph. H. 10.3.
all-sleepless, Opp. H. 2.659.
all-invisible, Eratosth. Cat. 23.
completely severed from companions of his own age, ἦμαρ ὀρφανικὸν παναφήλικα παῖδα τίθησιν Il. 22.490.
all-imperishable, ἦμαρ AP 7.14 (Antip. Sid.).
all-bountiful, epith. of Isis, POxy. 1380.88 (ii A.D.).
all-inevitable, βρόχος AP 9.396 ( Paul.Sil.); ζεῦγμα IG 3.1339.
all-leafless, h.Cer. 452.

all the Achaeans, Il. 2.404, al.: fem. Πᾰνᾰχαιά, ἡ, epith. of Demeter, Paus. 7.24.3; of Artemis, BCH 25.350 (Delph.):— also Πᾰνᾰχαιὶς γῆ, all Achaea, A.R. 1.243; Πᾰνᾰχαιίς, epith. of Athena, Paus. 7.20.2.
doomed to an untimely end, ἀλλʼ ἕνα παῖδα τέκεν π. Il. 24.540; π. ῥυτίς AP 5.263.5 ( Paul.Sil.).
all-knowing, Δημόκριτος Tz. H. 4.529.
richly carved, Pi. Fr. 75.5.
complete banquet at which no one and nothing fails, Hdt. 5.20, Ar. Pax 565, Is. Fr. 100, Plu. Suav. 2.1102a, Supp.Epigr. 4.304.6 ( Panamara), Alciphr. 3.18:—also πᾰν-δαίσιον, τό, Phot., Suid.
biting all, of Cato, Epigr. ap. Plu. Cat.Ma. 1.
all-tearful, ὀδύρματα S. Tr. 50.

children.label: II
children.definition: all-bewept, most miserable, γένος A. Th. 654; βιοτά S. Ph. 689 (lyr.); ἐφαμέρων ἔθνη E. Or. 976 (lyr.).
Hippon. 2 (vv. Il. πανδάληκτος, πανδαύληκτος, whence Bgk. proposes πανδαύχνητος, = πανδάφνωτος, all laurel-crowned).

the all-subduer, all-tamer, of sleep, Il. 24.5, Od. 9.373; of time, Simon. 4.5, B. 12.205, Epigr.Gr. 1050 ( Ephesus); π. δαίμων S. Ph. 1467 (anap.); κεραυνός Luc. Tim. 2, etc.:—pecul. fem. πανδᾰμάτειρα, Orph. H. 10.26, Epigr.Gr. 434.6 ( Petra), IG 12(5).303 ( Paros); πανδαμάτωρ μοῖρα Arist. Pepl. 43.
all-cowardly, all-miserable, Emp. 141, Opp. C. 3.230.
all-dreaded, Lyr.Adesp. 140, dub. in Pi. Fr. 189.

all-dreadful, terrible, πάνδεινον ἡ ἀδικία Pl. R. 610d, cf. 605c; πρᾶγμα D. 54.33, cf. Men. Sam. 212, Ruf. Fr. 69; πάνδεινα πεπονθέναι Luc. Prom. 8; πάνδεινόν [ἐστι] it is outrageous, D. 23.79, cf. PTeb. 27.34 (ii B. C.), Phld. Ir. p.86 W.

children.label: II
children.definition: very able, c. inf., Pl. Plt. 290b; ironically, D. 19.120.

definition: πανδέκτειρα, ἡ, pecul. fem. of sq., κοιλίη π. Hp. Ep. 23.

children.definition: all-receiver: in pl. πανδέκται, οἱ, name of a Universal Dictionary or Encyclopedia, such as those compiled by Tiro and Dorotheus, Gell. 13.9.
the Pandects, i.e. the law-books of Justinian, Cod.Just. 1.17.1.12, al.: sg., ὁ π., = Digesta, Id. Const. Δέδωκεν 1.
knavish like Pandeletus (cf. Cratin. 242), γνῶμαι Ar. Nu. 924, cf. Sch.ad loc.
= πανδερκής II, Ζεῦ π. βροτῶν E. El. 1177 (lyr.).
seen by all, B. 16.70.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., all-seeing, AP 9.525.17, Q.S. 2.443, Orph. Fr. 62.
secure fastener, prob. name of a knot, δήσας τινὰ πανδέτην PMag.Leid.V. 5.23.
all-receiving, Pl. Ti. 51a; ἀήρ Ph. 1.386; σῶμα Ocell. 2.3; φύσις Plu. An.procr. 2.1014d; μήτηρ ἁπάντων Orph. Fr. 315.3.

definition: πανδημεί or παν-μί, Dor. πανδᾱμεί or παν-μί A. Th. 296, Eu. 1038 (both lyr.):— Adv. of πάνδημος,

children.definition: with the whole people, in a mass or body, Hdt. 6.63, 7.120, al.; π. προπέμπεσθαι ἐπὶ θάνατον Isoc. 10.27; π., πανομιλεί A. Th. l.c., cf. Eu. l.c.; π. θύειν Th. 1.126; στρατεῦσαι Id. 5.33, cf. 1.73, 90, 4.42, Pl. Lg. 814a; παρεῖναι And. 3.18; ἐξελθεῖν Lys. 2.49; τὸν βάρβαρον π. δέκεσθαι Hdt. 7.144, cf. 6.16, 8.40, 72. [ -ῑ Trag. (nisi leg. -εί) ; -ῐ AP 5.43 ( Rufin.); written -ί in IG 12(2).526 A 8, B 2 ( Eresus, iv/iii B. C.), Ἀρχ. Δελτ. 9 παρ. 53 (ibid.); -εί in BGU 646.20 (ii A. D.).]
the whole people, π. ἐξάγειν Pl. Lg. 829b; π. καθιστάναι, of Theseus in Attica, Arist. Fr. 384, Plu. Thes. 25; πανδημίᾳ, as Adv., = πανδημεί, A. Supp. 607.
of or belonging to all the people, ἦλθε δʼ ἐπὶ πτωχὸς π. public beggar, Od. 18.1; π. ἄγρη a draught of all kinds of fish, AP 9.383.2.

βοῦς S. Aj. 175 (lyr.); ἀγών E. Alc. 1026; στέγαι Id. Ba. 227; π. πόλις, στρατός, the whole body of the city, of the army, S. Ant. 7, Aj. 844; π. χάρις general favour, Alcid. ap. Arist. Rh. 1406a26; δόξα Plb. 31.25.8; δεῖπνον IG 7.2712.79 (Acraeph.); ἀρχή Sammelb. 5765 (iii/ iv A. D.); of diseases, pandemic, Gal. 17(1).2; epith. of Zeus at Athens, IG 2(2).1075. Adv. -μως, = πανδημεί, τοὺς ἀνθρώπους εὐώχησε π. ib. 5(2).268.43 ( Mantinea).

children.label: II
children.definition: π. Ἔρως vulgar love, opp. οὐράνιος, Pl. Smp. 180e sq., cf. X. Smp. 8.9; π. Ἀφροδίτη Pl. Smp. 181a, IG 2(2).659, SIG 1014.57 ( Erythrae, iii B. C.), Paus. 1.22.3, Luc. DMeretr. 7.1, etc. (also in pl., Dam. Pr. 97 bis); π. ἐρασταί Pl. Smp. 181e; π. μουσική common, vulgar music, Aristox. Fr.Hist. 90; ἡ π. λέξις ordinary (common) speech, Phld. Rh. 1.165 S.
a festival of Zeus at Athens, D. 21.9, IG 2(2).1172.9.
all-righteous, φρήν S. Tr. 294; π. σέβας prob. in A. Supp. 776 (lyr.). Adv. -κως most justly, Id. Th. 172 (lyr.), 670, Ch. 241, S. OC 1306, E. Rh. 720 (lyr.); as in duty bound, S. Tr. 611, 1247.
son of Pandion, used of Pericles, Cratin. 56 (s. v.l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Πανδῑονίς, ίδος, daughter of Pandion, χελίδων Sapph. 88, cf. Hes. Op. 568.
Aeschin. 2.169, Harp.
all-divine, ῥίζα, = χελιδόνιον μέγα, Ps.- Dsc. 2.180 (Wellm. Πανδίονος ῥ.): pecul. fem., πανδῖα Σελήνη Max. 146; Π. alone, Id. 123.
hostess, Hdn.Gr. 1.248:—written παν-δόκια, IG 14.24 ( Syracuse).
trade of an innkeeper, Pl. Lg. 918d, Poll. 7.16.

inn, Ar. Ra. 550, D. 19.158, Aeschin. 2.97, IG 2(2).1638.30, Philippid. 25.2, Com.Adesp. 159, Plb. 2.15.5:—later πανδοχεῖον, Thphr. Lap. 53 codd., Aen.Tact. 10.10 codd., Str. 5.3.9, 12.8.17, etc., condemned by Phryn. 276.

one who receives all comers, innkeeper, Pl. Lg. 918b, Plb. 2.15.6, Arr. Epict. 1.24.14, Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.234e, etc.: metaph., πάσης κακίας π. Pl. R. 580a; π. Ἅιδης Lyc. 655:—later πανδοχεύς, Ev.Luc. 10.35; of the δεκάς, all-containing, Pythag. ap. Procl. in Ti. 3.107 D.; also Pythag. name for unity, Theol.Ar. 6.
Pl. Lg. 842d (pl.).
BGU 1468.3 ( iii/ii B. C., pl.).
hostess, Ar. Ra. 114, Pl. 426, Eup. 9, D.C. 46.6: metaph., φάλαινα π. a sea-monster ready to take all in, Ar. V. 35.

entertain as a host or innkeeper, Timocr. 1.10, Hdt. 4.95, Pl. Lg. 918e: abs., keep an inn or lodging-house, Thphr. Char. 6.5:— Pass., to be furnished with inns, ὅσα μέρη -εύεται κατὰ τὴν δίοδον D.H. 4.53.
take upon oneself, assume, ἅπαντα παιδείας ὄτλον A. Th. 18.
St.Byz. s.v. Καππαδοκία.

all-receiving, common to all, χέρσος, of Hades, A. Th. 860; of the sacred places at Elis and Delphi, Pi. O. 3.17, P. 8.61; π. ξενίαι Id. O. 4.17; π. ξενόστασις S. Fr. 274: c. gen., δόμοι π. ξένων A. Ch. 662.
-δοκος MAMA 3.576, al. ( Corycus); gen. -δοχος ib. 459 (ibid.): nom. sg. in Hsch.
absolute fame, perfect glory, Pi. N. 1.11.
one who gives herself to all, of a harlot, Anacr. 156, Com.Adesp. 1352.

Harm. 4):— Dim. παν-δούριον, τό, Hsch. and Phot. s.v. πηκτίς:—also παν-δουρίς, ίδος, ἡ, Hsch., Gloss.:—hence παν-δουρίζω, play the πανδοῦρα, Hist.Aug.Elag. 32; παν-δουριστής, οῦ, ὁ, one who plays it, Euph. Rh. 1408b15; π. εἶδος [τῆς ῥητορικῆς] Phld. Rh. 2.251 S.; τὰ π. Plu. Profect. 2.79b: Comp. -ώτερος, of Isocrates himself, D.H. Vett.Cens. 5.2; -ώτεραι διηγήσεις Aps. p.257 H.

definition: πανήγυρις, Dor. πανᾱγ-, εως, ἡ, ( πᾶς, ἄγυρις)

children.definition: general or national assembly, ἐν πανηγύρει βουλευσόμεσθα A. Ag. 845; esp. a festal assembly in honour of a national god, Δήμητρος ἁγνῆς καὶ Κόρης Archil. 120; Ζηνὸς ἀμφὶ πανάγυριν Pi. O. 9.96; πανηγύριας πανηγυρίζειν, ποιήσασθαι, to hold such festivals, keep holy-days, Hdt. 2.59, 58; συναγαγεῖν Isoc. 4.1; διαλύειν X. Cyr. 6.1.10; ἐς π. θεωρεῖν Ar. Pax 342; θεωρίαι ἐς τὰς ἐν τῇ Ἑλλάδι π. Decr. ap. D. 18.91; Ὀλυμπίαζε εἰς τὴν τῶν Ἑλλήνων π. ἐπανιών Pl. Hp.Mi. 363c; in Caria, PCair.Zen. 341 ( a) 11 (iii B. C.); in Egypt, PHib. 27.76 (iii B. C.), etc.; ἐν ταῖς π. καὶ δείξεσι τῶν σοφιστῶν Phld. Rh. 2.256S.; ἁμίλλαις ἱππικαῖς καὶ πανηγύρει προσκαθήμενος Jul. Or. 1.39c; π. ἐμπορικόν τι πρᾶγμα Str. 10.5.4, cf. CIG 4474.35 ( Baetocaece), Prisc.p.277 D.
